item.description:
Hadoop Cluster

RockyLinux9.3 && Docker && JDK8 && Hadoop3.2.4 (jdk21 is NOT compatible with hadoop3.4.0)

Basic Operations If Needed

mapping

  • vim /etc/hosts

append » “192.168.2.4 hostname”

close the firewall

  • systemctl stop firewalld
  • systemctl disable firewalld

handle JDK and hadoop env variable

in /etc/profile or ~/.bashrc:

export HADOOP_HOME=/root/Downloads/hadoop-3.2.4
export PATH=$PATH:$HADOOP_HOME/bin:$HADOOP_HOME/sbin

ssh config if needed

create public/private keys

  • ssh-keygen -t rsa

create authorized_keys and change mod

  • cd ~/.ssh
  • touch authorized_keys
  • chmod 600 authorized_keys

add public key into authorized_keys

  • cat id_rsa.pub » authorized_keys

create image

  • docker commit [container_id/name] [image_name]

Config master and slaves

create containers:

  • docker run -it [-v ~/hadoopMapping/hosts:/etc/hosts] -h master –name master ubuntu/hadoopinstalled

  • docker run -it [-v ~/hadoopMapping/hosts:/etc/hosts] -h slave01 –name slave01 ubuntu/hadoopinstalled

  • docker run -it [-v ~/hadoopMapping/hosts:/etc/hosts] -h slave02 –name slave02 ubuntu/hadoopinstalled

If needed(hostname <==> ip address), [-v path/hosts:/etc/hosts] or create new docker network.

add slave computer

vim /path/hadoop/etc/hadoop/workers,

replace localhost with the hostnames of two slaves.

Format and Start Hadoop

format

  • hadoop namenode -format

start && stop hadoop

  • start-all.sh
  • stop-all.sh

use hadoop

look through the hadoop process

  • jps

look through port service

  • netstat -tpnl | grep java

test:

brower » http://ip:8088

terminal » curl http://ip:8088/cluster

Reference

blog

Basic Operation

read folder and file information

  • hdfs dfs -ls [-R] [-h] /
    • recursive
    • human-readable

create/remove file/folder

  • hdfs dfs -mkdir -p /user/root
  • hdfs dfs -touchz /path/to/hdfs/emptyfile
  • hdfs dfs -rm [-rf] /path/to/hdfs/directory_or_file

judge existence and look through

  • hdfs dfs -test -e /user/root/demo.txt
  • echo $?
  • hdfs dfs -cat /user/root/demo.txt

upload && download && append file

  • hdfs dfs -put [-f] demo.txt /user/root
  • hdfs dfs -get demo.txt /root/
  • hdfs dfs -appendToFile /root/demo.txt /user/root/demo.txt
  • hdfs dfs -copyFromLocal [-f] /root/demo.txt /user/root/demo.txt

move or rename file

  • hdfs dfs -mv test.txt dir/test.txt

Hive Preparation

  1. hadoop3.2.4 has already been installed successfully
  2. downloaded hive 3.1.2 and mysql jdbc
  3. pull mysql image and run it
  • docker run -p 3306:3306 –name mysql -v /data:/data -e MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=123123 –privileged=true [images_name]

Config Mysql

install mysql client

  • apt-get update
  • apt-cache policy mysql-client
  • apt-get install mysql-client=8.0.?-?ubuntu?
  • mysql -h ?ip -P 3306 -u myuser -p

operate database

  • mysql> create database hive;
  • mysql> flush privileges;

mv mysql-connector-java-8.0.28.tar ~~/hive/lib

Hbase Preparation

  1. Hadoop has already been installed successfully.
  2. JDK8 && hadoop3.2.4 && hbase2.4.17 && zookeeper3.7.2

Zookeeper Config

  1. Download and install zookeeper in /usr/local(recommended)
  2. Run command: mv zoo_sample.cfg zoo.cfg in zookeeper/conf
  3. Modify zoo.cfg
1
2
3
4
5
6

dataDir=/usr/local/zookeeper/data
dataLogDir=/usr/local/zookeeper/log

server.1=master:2888:3888
server.2=slave01:2888:3888
server.3=slave02:2888:3888

  1. Copy the current folder and paste it to the other hosts

  2. In the ~~/zookeeper/data of each computer, create a file named ‘myid’ and write 1, 2, 3 in each respectively

  3. Start each PC respectively

  • /usr/local/zookeeper/bin/zkServer.sh start

​Look through the status

  • /usr/local/zookeeper/bin/zkServer.sh status

import happybase

try:
    # Connect to HBase
    connection = happybase.Connection('172.17.0.2', port=9090)

    # Get the names of all tables
    tables = connection.tables()

    # Print the names of all tables
    print("Names of all tables:")
    for table_name in tables:
        print(table_name.decode('utf-8'))

    # Close the connection
    connection.close()

except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error connecting to HBase: {e}")
